awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Environmental influence and mechanisms underlying subgenome dominance in Camelina sativa
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Plant Genome Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Dr. Jordan Brock is "Environmental influence and mechanisms underlying subgenome dominance in Camelina sativa". The host institutions for the fellowship are Michigan State University and Boyce Thompson Institute and the sponsoring scientists are Dr. Patrick Edger and Dr. Andrew Nelson.

Many agriculturally important plants are the product of hybridization events in which the genomes of two or more parental species come together to form a new species (e.g., canola, cotton, or wheat). These plants, known as polyploids, are often more resistant to environmental stress because they have multiple copies of each gene (from their parental subgenomes) providing a larger toolkit for overcoming challenges. However, little is known about the degree to which polyploids preferentially utilize genes of different parental origin to overcome environmental challenges. This project will address the role parental subgenomes play in overcoming environmental stresses in the polyploid biofuel crop, camelina. Specifically, this work will address the role of temperature in determining subgenome bias in seed oil production. Through interrogation of the mechanisms behind environmentally determined responses by the underlying genetics encoded by each subgenome, this work will provide the genomic understanding and resources for the development of more resilient crops. The fellow will receive technical training in genomics, epigenomics, and bioinformatics. Outreach in plant biology and genomics will be conducted in K-12 schools through a biofuel education module, in addition to the mentoring and training of undergraduate researchers.

This project aims to use genomic techniques to understand the relative contribution of each subgenome in the regulation of abiotic stress (temperature) with regard to seed oil production in Camelina sativa. Camelina, an emerging aviation biofuel crop, is the product of a hybridization and whole-genome duplication between two parental species, C. hispida and C. neglecta. The quality and composition of camelina oil is known to be influenced greatly by environmental conditions such as temperature. This project will employ transcriptome and bisulfite sequencing to understand how expression-levels among subgenomes change relative to each other as a consequence of temperature stress. Camelina sativa and its two diploid parental species will be grown together in varying environmental conditions and developing seeds will be extracted at multiple timepoints. Transcriptome and DNA methylation libraries will be sequenced across distinct developmental stages of the seed, and in varying environments, to examine subgenome-specific contributions. One hypothesis is that polyploid plants have the ability to regulate subgenome expression such that the subgenome most adapted to the current environment will be more dominantly expressed. Additionally, DNA methylation patterns across C. sativa subgenomes will be examined to understand the mechanisms behind subgenome expression level dominance. Data generated in this project will be presented in peer-reviewed publications, and transcriptomic and epigenomic data generated will be made publicly available in National Center for Biotechnology Information databases. All other data, including phenotypic data, will be made publicly available in Dryad.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Research – 

This research focused on understanding the ability of plants to respond plastically to their environment. Many species of plants, including some of the world’s most important crop species, are polyploids, meaning that they have multiple genomes and sets of genes available for expression. Understanding how such polyploid species utilize their genes, and whether they can preferentially use versions of genes (homoeologs) that may be adapted to particular environments is of broad interest to the fields of biological evolution and agricultural improvement. My research focused on the allopolyploid Camelina sativa, as well as its diploid progenitor species, C. hispida and C. neglecta. Controlled growth chamber experiments were conducted on these species and other Camelina species, exposing them to conditions mimicking warm environments and cool environments, and RNA-seq was performed to understand how homoeologous genes were being transcribed among the subgenomes of C. sativa. Many previous studies in polyploid crops have shown expression dominance, where genes from one subgenome are expressed at higher levels than those of other subgenomes, although little was known about how this occurs at a mechanistic level or how it might be modulated by environmental factors.


As an additional resource related to this project I sequenced and assembled a higher quality reference genome for C. sativa using long-read sequencing technology. As a consequence, the majority of gaps were filled relative to the previous genome assembly for C. sativa. With this new, high-quality genomic resource, RNAseq reads were able to be more accurately mapped to their respective subgenomes thus reducing false-signal. This resulted in a large reduction in observed expression dominance in C. sativa in all tissue-types, relative to what was previously observed in this species. This suggests that the phenomenon of expression dominance in C. sativa that was previously described appears to be at least in part due to artifacts of using previous-generation reference genome assemblies. Interestingly, these data show that while environment elicits a strong response in expression changes of individual genes, no significant difference in expression between subgenomes across environments was observed. This indicates that there is likely hardwiring of relative gene expression among subgenomes, that might be established immediately upon initial hybridization or in early generations post-polyploidization.

 

I expanded my research question to include other study species in order to address whether expression hardwiring was unique to Camelina or represents a more broad phenomenon. Thus, complimentary analyses were conducted in Fragaria (Strawberry) species, Gossypium hirsutum (Cotton), and Brassica rapa (Rapeseed). These experiments revealed several valuable insights for genomics, and crop improvement. Interestingly, when mapping RNAseq data from these species to newer, high quality reference genomes, the degree of subgenome expression dominance was found to be diminished. Furthermore, differences in environment (temperature) and abiotic stress (drought) in these experiments was not found to produce any large shifts of expression dominance from one subgenome to any other.


Training, Professional Development, and Mentoring –

This project has offered a variety of professional development, mentoring, and training opportunities. I had the opportunity to mentor undergraduate students in the lab, providing them with experience in the fields of plant sciences and genomics. As a part of my outreach activities, I developed a fully transferrable biofuels educational module aimed at K-12 students including a supplies list and instructions along with video demonstrations and interactive components. The module allows students to extract oil from Camelina and learn how it can be converted into renewable jet fuel, fostering an understanding of the importance of biofuels and renewable energies. During the duration of the fellowship, I had the opportunity to gain experience in teaching undergraduate level classes in plant genomics. Further, I gained experience and new skillsets including coding in R and Python and comparative genomic analyses, significantly improving my computational skills. The skills that I have honed during my NSF fellowship provide me with a strong base with which to continue growing my career in genomics research.
